column16: Description of Program
column18: Ave. # of hours of all digital programming per week
column19: Ave. # of hours per week of digital Core Programming per week
column20: Y or N to Q 11 in Digital Core Programming: At least 50% of the Core Programming had not already aired within the previous seven days

column16: This two-hour program block features three half-hour educational series in combination with several short-form educational elements. The latter includes "Great Minds...Think For Themselves" (American history segments) and "Where'd It Go?" (short segments describing animal behavior). Disney's Doug -- Narrated via the spoken journal entries of aspiring writer/cartoonist Doug Funnie, this series uses humor and fantasy in depicting the struggles of a twelve-year-old boy to define identity, develop self-confidence, resolve family and school problems and maintain friendships strained by preadolescent physical and emotional change. Series episodes promote values such as honesty, loyalty, fairness and respect for individual differences. Disney's Pepper Ann -- "Pepper Ann" features a twelve-year-old girl who is growing up in a single-parent family. She demonstrates that individuality, competence and humor are survival skills for any pre-teenager. From week to week Pepper Ann discovers the importance of speaking out for what one believes and the value of learning from one's mistakes. The primary educational focus of the series is self-esteem - particularly that of young girls. Additionally, the series teaches perseverance, taking responsibility and thinking creatively. Disney's Recess -- "Disney's Recess" is a collection of animated stories about six fourth graders who attend suburban public school. Loyal friends, these children are an ethnically and gender-diverse group. They provide role models for viewers who may be struggling with problems common to middle childhood such as conflicts with authority figures, school and family rules, issues of fairness, desire to be popular, peer pressure and crises of confidence. A recurrent theme is the problem of dealing with the class bully or "teacher's pet." Series episodes raise thought-provoking questions which parents and children can talk about together, providing a rich source of values-oriented family discussion material. [Note: Dec. 19 preemption was caused by ABC Network News coverage of impeachment hearings, Iraq military operation, and related coverage. The preempted episode was not rebroadcast.]

This series addresses many of the key developmental issues of middle childhood. A group of Dalmatian puppies and a resourceful chicken named "Spot" are featured in stories that center on problem-solving. Plots frequently introduce conflicts over rules, learning responsibility, attempts to gain peer acceptance, learning from mistakes and efforts to help other animals or human characters. The series encourages prosocial values such as empathy, fairness and cooperative behavior, as well as modeling information-gathering and strategic thinking. [Note: Dec. 19 preemption was caused by ABC Network News coverage of impeachment hearings, Iraq military operation, and related coverage. The preempted episode was not rebroadcast.]

column7: The New Adventures of Winnie the Pooh
column16: Based on the classic Winnie The Pooh books by author A.A. Milne, "The New Adventures Of Winnie The Pooh" depicts the everyday lives of Christopher Robin and his animal companions Pooh, Piglet, Rabbit, Tigger, Eeyore, Owl and Gopher. Stories convey strong prosocial messages about honesty, taking responsibility, persistence, cooperative effort, friendship and caring. Episodes selected for the 1998-99 package present stories having greatest educational relevance to younger viewers. Many of these stories are designed to help younger children distinguish between fantasy and reality, identify feelings and overcome common childhood fears. [Note: Dec. 19 preemption was caused by ABC Network News coverage of impeachment hearings, Iraq military operation, and related coverage. The preempted episode was not rebroadcast.]

Primarily designed for children in the middle school grades, "Squigglevision" uses activities at a radio station and in the courtroom as springboards for teaching scientific concepts and their everyday applications. Characters use critical thinking to examine and describe phenomena, thereby helping the home viewer to sharpen observational and sequential thinking skills. They demonstrate both inductive and deductive reasoning and evaluate hypotheses in light of data obtained and make judgments. Scientific and math estimation concepts are illustrated by means of practical "demonstrations" and graphics. [Note: Dec. 19 preemption was caused by ABC Network News coverage of impeachment hearings, Iraq military operation, and related coverage. The preempted episode was not rebroadcast.]

A forum for kids to think and ask questions about the world around them; give kids a way to obtain information and background they need to understand world events; give kids a way of using news as a part of their lives and feel good about wanting to know more.

A music magazine show that explores how ideas and dreams become reality. Viewers are taken on musical adventures, delving into features on everything from how they make crayons to what it takes to be a professional beekeeper. Through original music, processes and professions are explained in rhythm and rhyme.

This short-form educational program teaches concepts in grammar, math, U.S. history, science and finance by transforming these concepts into popular song, rhyme and amusing visuals. This method of presenting academic concepts has proven to be a powerful instructional tool.

This short-form educational program teaches concepts in grammar, math, U.S. history, science and finance by transforming these concepts into popular song, rhyme and amusing visuals. This method of presenting academic concepts has proven to be a powerful instructional tool.

column7: ABC Kids Movie Matinee: Disney's One Saturday Morning Crush Marathon
column16: Selected episodes of "Disney's Doug," "Disney's Recess" and "Disney's Pepper Ann" portray the experience of falling in love or being the object of a youthful "crush." Disney's Doug -- Narrated via the spoken journal entries of aspiring writer/cartoonist Doug Funnie, this series uses humor and fantasy in depicting the struggles of a twelve-year-old boy to define identity, develop self-confidence, resolve family and school problems and maintain friendships strained by preadolescent physical and emotional change. Series episodes promote values such as honesty, loyalty, fairness and respect for individual differences. Disney's Pepper Ann -- "Pepper Ann" features a twelve-year-old girl who is growing up in a single-parent family. She demonstrates that individuality, competence and humor are survival skills for any pre-teenager. From week to week Pepper Ann discovers the importance of speaking out for what one believes and the value of learning from one's mistakes. The primary educational focus of the series is self-esteem - particularly that of young girls. Additionally, the series teaches perseverance, taking responsibility and thinking creatively. Disney's Recess -- "Disney's Recess" is a collection of animated stories about six fourth graders who attend suburban public school. Loyal friends, these children are an ethnically and gender-diverse group. They provide role models for viewers who may be struggling with problems common to middle childhood such as conflicts with authority figures, school and family rules, issues of fairness, desire to be popular, peer pressure and crises of confidence. A recurrent theme is the problem of dealing with the class bully or "teacher's pet." Series episodes raise thought-provoking questions which parents and children can talk about together, providing a rich source of values-oriented family discussion material.

column7: ABC Kids Movie Matinee: Doug's Quail Man Marathon
column16: In the guise of imaginary superhero "QuailMan," Doug attempts to resolve some of his personal conflicts. With superhero canine "QuailDog" and his ally "Super Skeeter," Doug/QuailMan conquers nefarious characters and foils their selfish plots. These characters bear a striking resemblance to Guy, Roger and other mean or arrogant people in Doug's community. The story "QuailDad" is particularly nice in that QuailMan/Doug comes to realize that his father is a very talented and resourceful person -- not a klutz, as he thought, but a real-life hero.

This ABC Children's Special collects four episodes of "Disney's Recess" into a one-hour special presentation. "Disney's Recess" is a collection of animated stories about six fourth graders who attend suburban public school. Loyal friends, these children are an ethnically and gender-diverse group. They provide role models for viewers who may be struggling with problems common to middle childhood such as conflicts with authority figures, school and family rules, issues of fairness, desire to be popular, peer pressure and crises of confidence. A recurrent theme is the problem of dealing with the class bully or "teacher's pet." Series episodes raise thought-provoking questions which parents and children can talk about together, providing a rich source of values-oriented family discussion material.

This ABC Children's Special collects four episodes of "Disney's Pepper Ann" into a one-hour special presentation. "Disney's Pepper Ann" features a twelve-year-old girl who is growing up in a single-parent family. She demonstrates that individuality, competence and humor are survival skills for any pre-teenager. From week to week Pepper Ann discovers the importance of speaking out for what one believes and the value of learning from one's mistakes. The primary educational focus of the series is self-esteem - particularly that of young girls. Additionally, the series teaches perseverance, taking responsibility and thinking creatively.

This program is specifically designed to educate and inform children between the ages of 6 and 11 years old. More specifically, the series is designed to teach children in an entertaining way about fairly sophisticated scientific concepts.

The educational objective of this program is to demonstrate how the knowledge of one or more characters in the story moves one level to a more informed or higher level of knowledge by the end of each episode. This change in knowledge conveys an educational message to the audience which may fall into one or more categories—intellectual-cognitive and/or socio-emotional. The message will always be integral to the plot and present throughout the script. This objective is achieved in this series by showing how a group of teens deals with gender equality, competition, cooperation, and balancing priorities.

The educational objective of this program is to demonstrate how the knowledge of one or more characters in the story moves one level to a more informed or higher level of knowledge by the end of each episode. This change in knowledge conveys an educational message to the audience which may fall into one or more categories—intellectual-cognitive and/or socio-emotional. The message will always be integral to the plot and present throughout the script. This objective is achieved in this series by showing how a group of teens deals with gender equality, competition, cooperation, and balancing priorities.

The educational objective of this program is to introduce the teen audience to the pro-social, off-court activities of basketball players and other individuals, and to individuals who have overcome various obstacles in order to achieve their goals. The program segments are based on a curriculum inspired by the U.S. Department of Education’s Goals 2000, with particular focus on messages encouraging the following values: school completion, community service, cooperation, tolerance of differences, healthful practices and athletics, peaceful conflict resolutions and global awareness. These educational and informational messages are conveyed primarily through real life examples, interviews and commentary by the program’s hosts.

The educational objective of this program is to demonstrate how the knowledge of one or more characters in the story moves from one level to a more informed or higher level of knowledge by the end of each episode. This change in knowledge conveys an educational message to the audience which may fall into one or more categories—intellectual-cognitive and/or socio-emotional. The message will always be integral to the plot and present throughout the script. This objective is achieved through this series by exploring social themes through the daily school life of six teenage friends at Bayside High who help each other make the most of growing up in a complicated world. The Bayside kids give teens a useful perspective on many of the tough issues they have to face both in their peer relationships, and in personal decision-making both in and out of the classroom.

The educational objective of this program is to demonstrate how the knowledge of one or more characters in the story moves from one level to a more informed or higher level of knowledge by the end of each episode. This change in knowledge conveys an educational message to the audience which may fall into one or more categories—intellectual-cognitive and/or socio-emotional. This message will always be integral to the plot and present throughout the script. This objective is achieved through this series by exploring socio-emotional themes of identity, self-worth, social reciprocity, service to others and acceptance of differences. Through the characters in the show, our audience will see examples of different approaches to resolving problems caused by these issues.

The educational objective of this program is to demonstrate how the knowledge of one or more characters in the story moves from one level to a more informed or higher level of knowledge by the end of each episode. This change in knowledge conveys an educational message to the audience which may fall into one or more categories—intellectual-cognitive and/or socio-emotional. The message will always be integral to the plot and present throughout the script. This objective is achieved in this series by exploring the pressures of living in an big city environment where situations are sometimes so difficult and challenging, kids have to learn sophisticated and responsible decision-making to be safe and stay focused. The series follows the encounters and problem-solving of two young men through an eventful year at Manhattan High and shows teens how to work with their principal, family and friends to be successful.

Click is a game of speed and knowledge in which adolescent teams compete to provide correct and rapid answers to different types of questions and challenges. The educational objectives are: provide a positive learning context for the acquisition of knowledge; stimulate interest in intellectual activities; foster rapid thinking and information retrieval; to enhance adolescents’ capacity to "think on their feet," to develop the ability to decode and recognize alternative representations of words and to enhance responsiveness to non-verbal as well as verbal cues; to promote the acquisition of specific knowledge in diverse content areas; to demonstrate that intellectual activities can be rewarding and fun; to demonstrate the value of cooperation in intellectual tasks.

Host Rob Hambree teaches children not to be too proud, the importance of being responsible, having a willing and obedient attitude, using good judgment, the meaning of real love, not taking revenge and how to have good friendships with others.

Host Rosey Grier takes a look a look at issues about crime like a juvenile court, how to stay away from drugs, standing up for your right to live free, and how to be aware of your surroundings. He also takes a serious look at issues such as suicide.
This program teaches children how to develop self-control, patience, kindness, and love. It teaches children how to be gentle and helpful, as well as how to respect others and how to make friends.

This program teaches children how to be effective leaders and good citizens, as well as lessons on how to combat peer pressure, deal with persecution, use their strengths, and how to trust God during difficult situations.

The host of this program teaches children to sing, fun exercises, the alphabet, and how to use the library. The children also learn the importance of reading, as well as principles of science like electricity.

This program teaches children how to take responsibility for their actions. It teaches listening skills and how to avoid being deceived. It also teaches children how to set priorities, how not to jump to conclusions and the importance of following instructions.

This program teaches children the importance of maintaining good physical condition. It stresses personal qualities like perserverance and honesty. Lessons are usually taught by example and analogies.

The setting of this program is an old western town where Gospel Bill and the rest of the townspeople teach children life lessons. They teach children lessons on respect, honesty, healthy living, how not to exact revenge, how to resist using bad language and keep a good attitude.
Kids On The Move informs and educates children about historical information found in the Bible. The program incorporates questions and contestants in a "game show" format.

Host Rosey Grier takes a look a look at issues about crime like a juvenile court, how to stay away from drugs, standing up for your right to live free, and how to be aware of your surroundings. He also takes a serious look at issues such as suicide.
Superbook is an animation series that teaches history by presenting biblical figures and events. Children are taught forgiveness, love, and overcoming trials and adversity.
Kids On The Move informs and educates children about historical information found in the Bible. The program incorporates questions and contestants in a "game show" format.
This program teaches children how to listen, develop good manners, cooperation, how to resist temptation and how to forgive. The program also teaches responsibility and patience.

This program teaches children about things like dealing with anger, bitterness, alcoholism and stealing is wrong. It reinforces loving others, kindness, sharing, and protecting the faithful and innocent.

This program teaches children how to be effective leaders and good citizens, as well as lessons on how to combat peer pressure, deal with persecution, using their strengths, and how to trust God during difficult situations.

This program teaches children how to say and do the "right" things, how to develop good habits and how to break bad ones. It teaches patriotism, and perseverance, as well as how to make love a priority and to follow good role models.

Dav Pilkey's book series published by Scholastic, provides the basis for this program about a family of extremely naive bunnies, who use their idiosyncratic, nontraditional logic to solve problems. The objectives of the program are to introduce children to some principle of and creative approaches to problem-solving by exposing them to divergent ways of thinking, and to help them understand the importance of family relationships built on mutual respect, trust and cooperation and the value of various positive personal and social behaviors. This program is specifically designed to further the educational and informational needs of children, has educating and informing children as a significant purpose, and otherwise meets the definition of Core Programming as specified in the Commission's rules Note: This program was Preempted on CBS Network on 12/19 due to Impeachment Hearings. On ll/14 CBS broadcast a Special Report on the Iraq Crisis which interrupted this program from 7:19a-7:30a.

In this series, four friends at Flying Rhino Junior High uses brains and brawn to deal with problems created by their nemesis Earl P. Sidebottom, who can transpose the school to faraway places and drop students into strange situations. Focusing episodically on the different members of the group, the program addresses a range of personal and social concerns faced by early adolescents, while integrating school curricular material relating to the language and creative arts, science, and history, as well as principles of critical thinking and problem solving. This program is specifically designed to further the educational and informational needs of children, has educating and informing children as a significant purpose, and otherwise meets the definition of Core Programming as specified in the Commission's rules. Note: This program was preempted by CBS Network on 12/19 to Impeachment Hearings.

This program teaches children the value of learning to make things with their own hands, from making a home garden to a bird house. It teaches children the rewards of building something from scratch by themselves. This program is specifically designed to further the educational and informational needs of children, has educating and informing children as a significant purpose, and otherwise meets the definition of Core Programming as specified in the Commission's rules. Note: This program was preempted by Coverage of the Impeachment Hearings on 12/19. Also interrupted by CBS coverage of Iraq Crisis on 11/14 at 8:24am to 8:30am.

This program explores the limits of science, technology and imagination. Popular Mechanics for Kids stimulates kids curiosity of "how things work". This program is specifically designed to further the educational and informational needs of children, has educating and informing children as a significant purpose, and otherwise meets the definition of core Programming as specified in the Commission's rules. Note: This program was preempted on 12/19 due to coverage of the Impeachment Hearings. Also, on 11/14, this program was joined in progress at 8:38 am. due to CBS report on Irag Crisis.

In this series, children are exposed to a variety of issues facing young teenagers as seen through the eyes of a family of birds, led by the 12-year old Eddie Storkowitz, an aspiring filmmaker. The program focuses on coming-of-age problems related to self-esteem, peer pressure, interpersonal relationships, social roles, and civility. This program is specifically designed to further the educational and informational needs of children, has educating and informing children as a significant purpose, and otherwise meets the definition of Core Programming as specified in the Commission's rules. Note this program was on the CBS Network on 12/19 due to Impeachment Hearings.

This series uses the amusing though engagingly ghoulish character the Cryptkeeper, well known to both elementary school aged and adolescent children, as a storyteller who introduces young viewers to a variety of life lessons. The objectives of the program are to assist children in learning lessons such as the importance of staying in school, the value of telling the truth and being considerate of others, and the need to exercise judgment in choosing friends, and to help viewers understand principles of self-discipline needed to solve personal problems. This program is specifically designed to further the educational and informational needs of children, has educating and informing children as a significant purpose, and otherwise meets the definition of Core Programming as specified in the Commission’s rules.

column7: Mythic Warriors: Guardians of the Legend
column16: Based on the Children's Choice award-winning books by Laura Geringer, this adventure series uses a modernized Mount Olympus to introduce children to the stories of classic Greek myths and legends, related by a storyteller who emphasizes questions of right and wrong, loyalty and ethical conduct. The program teaches positive life lessons, such as the value of personal determination, courage and compassion, while cultivating an appreciation of reading and the storytelling tradition. This program is specifically designed to further the educational and informational needs of children, has educating and informing children as a significant purpose, and otherwise meets the definition of core Programming as specified in the Commission's rules.

Based on a series by Paulette Bourgeois and Brenda Clark, this program features the adventures of the turtle Franklin and his friends Bear, Snail, Rabbit and Goose. The objectives of the program are to present to young viewers age-appropriate moral dilemmas addressing issues such as the meaning of right and wrong, the purpose of rules and the consequences of following or not following them, and the values inherent in telling the truth, and to teach viewers important social values such as cooperation and compromise, fairness, responsibility, self-respect and respect for others. This program is specifically designed to further the educational and informational needs of children, has educating and informing children as a significant purpose, and otherwise meets the definition of Core Programming as specified in the Commission's rules.

From the Caldecott award winning series by Eve Titus, this program follows the escapades of Anatole the mouse, who learns to function in both worlds of humans and mice by being clever, determined, a hard worker, a dedicated husband and father, and a problem-solver. The objectives of the program are to encourage viewers to identify and select positive alternatives when faced with personal, interpersonal and social dilemmas and to teach children that dedication and personal effort make it possible to be better family members, friends, students, workers and citizens. This program is specifically designed to further the educational and informational needs of children, has educating and informing children as a significant purpose, and otherwise meets the definition of Core Programming as specified in the Commission's rules.

The series Bobby's World is an imaginative, entertaining and informative program which deals with the challenges of growing up. Each episode offers children an opportunity to learn how to cope with the complexities of the world for young children as well as teaches the importance of family, friends and values.

Life with Louie offers young viewers answers to issues that are common to growing up, but might be perplexing to a young child. Each episode offers children an opportunity to learn how to cope with family and friends as a part of growing up. As children view this series, not only are they being entertained, they are learning valuable life lessons.

Scholastic's The Magic School Bus is an animated science adventure series. In every episode, viewers will be transported into a variety of science situations, such as inside a volcano, a baker's oven for a heated experience in chemistry or to the edge of the solar system.
Disney's Doug is designed to educate and inform children who are between the ages of two and eleven. The series teaches children about the fundamentals, morals and educational lessons in life.
Young America Outdoors is an entertaining and informative series which not only teaches children the importance of taking care of our environment, it also teaches them how to use the outdoors safely.

The series Bobby's world is an imaginative, entertaining and informative program which deals with the challenges of growing up. Each episode offers children an opportunity to learn how to cope with the complexities of the world for young children as well as teaches the importance of family, friends and values.

The television program is geared towards young children and stars Bloopy, a colorful life-sized costume character child-like in nature, and a rich cast of adult-like Buddies. Together in Bloopyville they show young viewers the importance of exercise, health, nutrition and safety trhough the unique B.E.L.L. philosophy: Be Well, Eat Well, Live Well, Learn Well. Alliances have been forged with non-profit eduational partners such as the American Academy of Pediatrics, The American Heart Association, and the Children's Better Health Institute. Bloopy's Buddies is a recipient of a Parent's Choice Gold Award for best children's television series. Joining Bloopy and his buddies is the legendary actor and comedian Jonathan Winters. With his unique brand of storytelling, Winters, delivers meaningful lessons that entertain and teach children. A specific goal of the series is to create an entertaining and educational program that children can enjoy with their parents and grandparents. Learning experiences seen on Bloopy's Buddies can subsequently be reinforced with an adult's guidance and support. By addressing the issues of health and wellness in a fun and entertaining format, the producers have created something very special. Bloopy and his buddies encourage kids to get offthe couch and "Bloopycise," the first ever exercise format on television for young children.

This program recognizes the importance of academic excellence, encourages acquisition of knowledge, and rewards young people who demonstrate both intellectual prowess and the willingness to compete in an academic arena. This locally produced program is a weekly academic competition featuring two high school teams from the Northwest. Each show features 50 question/answers…five questions each in ten different categories. These categories include topics in geography, world history, American history, literature, science, arts and entertainment, sports, math, languages, ethnic cultures, and assorted other subjects. Students (in-studio and at home) are given the opportunity to use their educational skills in an exciting competition. Hollywood Video’s High Five Challenge is interactive and encourages young people to think and participate by utilizing their skills they have learned in school.. It provides a positive way for kids to exercise their mind and acquire knowledge. In addition it makes learning socially prestigious and encourages kids to remain engaged in intellectual pursuits. Thousands of dollars in scholarships have been handed out to schools participating on Hollywood Video’s High Five Challenge.

In each episode the cameras follow Jack, the show’s host, as he spends time with nature’s creatures across the continents. Jack talks with people that are knowledgeable about each animal and habitat, teaching as he goes. Children laugh and learn with Jack about the existence and importance of insects, mammals, birds, reptiles and other exotic creatures to our ecological systems. The program is designed to reveal to children the world around them in a way that presents positive role models and pro-social values within an environmentally responsible universe. This program has been endorsed by the National Education Association.

This weekly half-hour educational series is interactive and designed so that children can play along with the characters and solve a weekly science puzzle themselves. At Algo's FACTory, science isn't just demonstrated, it's wrapped up in adventure and fun. Wild animation and music rock the FACTory where the series' host, Al, a famous scientist and explorer, and Algo Rhythm, an animated chip who lives inside the Big computer, reside. The FACTory is a fantastic place stuffed with gadgets, gizmos and gears; where new marvels arrive every day and serious science is presented in a fun, exciting package.

A trio of live-action teen angels have taken on the task of broadcasting children's programs hoping to inspire and inform children through their own issues which correspond to the many moral lessons depicted through the long-form programs they broadcast. The long-form programs (as further described below) are informational and educational for children ages 5-9. ZAK TALES - Zak is the Mayor of Fun Town. The costumed Zak offers children solutions to the universal problems associated with growing up by drawing examples from classic children's literature and with characters in similar plights, such as Robinson Crusoe, Tom Thumb and Sinbad. Zak and his sidekick, Kilroy, lead their viewers on adventures filled with exciting stories, jokes, sing-alongs and even a little rap poetry. THE SYLVANIAN FAMILIES - This animated series of bears, rabbits, racoons, mice, beavers and foxes who live in the Sylvanian forest show that they have troubles like everyone else: fires, floods and storms. The villain Packbat and his sidekick, Gatorpossum, add to their troubles. The Sylvanian Families band together to solve every problem. Illustrating what a family is all about and allowing the audience to become a part of the family through their adventures. Some themes include pulling togehter, sharing resources and doing the right thing. THE TOOTHBRUSH FAMILY - The animated characters who live in the bathroom explore their environment on exciting adventures. The two brand new toothbrushes, Molly & Max, work with their friends, Flash, Fluoride & Susie Sponge, to become responsible toothbrushes, relating to children on their way to becoming responsible grown-ups. GET ALONG GANG - In Green Meadows, there lives a merry group of animated animal friends, The Get Along Gang, who are always ready to lend a helping hand in their own caring and clever way. They travel through the countryside in the Clubhouse Caboose, sharing adventures and stories presenting themes illustrating respect, trust, teamwork, helping others in need and responsibility. FOR DECEMBER 5, 1998, ONLY, THE ABOVE-LONG FORM PROGRAMMING WAS REPLACED BY THE FOLLOWING: SWISS FAMILY ROBINSON - The classic literary tale comes to life in this complelling live-action series. The show is shot on Fiji in the South Pacific and chronicles the story of the loving, closely-knit Robinson family as they face day-to-day struggles of being shipwrecked on a deserted island, far from home. Whether they are battling pirates, facing personal family tragedy or surviving Mother Nature, the Swiss Family Robinson demonstrates that family unity, honesty and goodness can triumph in the end. INQUIRING MINDS - An engaging magazine-format show designed to investigate many of the questions about everyday life, such as: why is the ocean salty, why chili peppers are hot and why skin itches. Some things not found in everyday life are also discussed, such as: how one can really walk on hot coals. By adding vivid demonstrations, fun sound effects, real photos, contemporary music and some clever graphics, the answers to some of life's most puzzling questions are revealed. It helps children learn how to think things through and how science fits into everyday life. SUPER MARIO BROTHERS - This animated series based on the characters from the Nintendo video game illustrates good versus evil. King Koopa and his daughter Kootie Pie battle to control the world as the Mario Brothers (Mario and Luigi), the Princess and Toad work to save the day. The show demonstrates working together, the bad side of greed and how learning new things will benefit you.

The trio of live-action angels continue with their task of broadcasting children's programs in hope of inspiring and informing children. We see them behind the scenes in the Cloud 9 studio where they work together to run the station while dealing with their own personal problems and work dilemmas that correspond to the many moral lessons depicted in the programs they broadcast. Each long-form segement serves to highlight and reinforce the educational and moral elements of the series. Overall themes include overcoming fears, being responsible, dealing with jealousy, respecting others, handling anger, learning to trust, resolving conflict, having a good attitude and self-esteem, using teamwork and being cooperative, being prepared, helping others, discouraging cheating and lying and promoting hard work and dedication. The long-form segments are targeted to children 6-10 and descriptions of these segments follow: SWISS FAMILY ROBINSON - The classic literary tale comes to life in this complelling live-action series. The show is shot on Fiji in the South Pacific and chronicles the story of the loving, closely-knit Robinson family as they face day-to-day struggles of being shipwrecked on a deserted island, far from home. Whether they are battling pirates, facing personal family tragedy or surviving Mother Nature, the Swiss Family Robinson demonstrates that family unity, honesty and goodness can triumph in the end. INQUIRING MINDS - An engaging magazine-format show designed to investigate many of the questions about everyday life, such as: why is the ocean salty, why chili peppers are hot and why skin itches. Some things not found in everyday life are also discussed, such as: how one can really walk on hot coals. By adding vivid demonstrations, fun sound effects, real photos, contemporary music and some clever graphics, the answers to some of life's most puzzling questions are revealed. It helps children learn how to think things through and how science fits into everyday life. HURRICANES - The excitement of chapionship soccer comes to life, with all the behind-the-scenes, off-the-field drama and action this animated series can bring. The show features a cast of international soccer players as members of the Hurricanes, who travel to exotic locales around the world. Thanks to an unexpected inheritance, an American teenager, Amanda, becomes the new owner of the team. Set on the island of Hipaniola, the characters include the diverse, international personalities who make up the team, an eccentric coach, his son, the physician and one unruly mascot. The series teaches teamwork, competition, winning and losing, and how to handle the moments of glory and defeat. US SPACE FORCE - The race for knowledge and the fight to defend freedom are at the heart of the courageous adventure of Starcom. Starcom, along with Starbase Command, Airwing and the Astro Marines are the premiere peacekeeping force in the growing planetary commuity. The heroes are a team of the best and brightest, making full use of their ultra-sophisticated vehicles and state-of-the-art technology to confront the sinister Emperor Dark. This animated show of heros, exploration, adventure and excitement set against the backdrop of colonization of the Solar System shows the cooperative efforts to keep the peace. Similarities can be drawn to the growing, changing children's environment.

A fast-paced comedy explores well-known and not so well-known moments in world history through quick comedy sketches, informational bits and songs. Special guests like George Washington, Napoleon, Confucious and Shakespeare lead you on a whirlwind tour through their points in time.

A fast-paced comedy explores well-known and not so well-known moments in world history through quick comedy sketches, informational bits and songs. Special guests like George Washington, Shakespeare, Confucious and Napoleon lead you on a whirliwind tour through their points in time.
A weekly field trip taken by a group of children and the host to interesting locations and learn about it's purpose.

Half hour live action program designed as an educational, informative and entertaining career guidance show for teens. Its hosts introduce the viewers to some of the worlds colorful and challenging careers.

This program takes children on fascinating awesome adventures each week. They'll experience volcanic explorations, the rapids of the Salmon River and safari's in Africa. Kids will learn the histories and cultures of the places they visit.

A search and rescue themed animal adventure series with an entertaining twist of investigative and detective super sleuthing by a group of neighborhood kids, a couple of veterinarians and a zany professor. Quality family entertainment that is fun and has educational value.
